The Bodhisattva stayed a little while in that place. Then he asked, "How far it is to Kapilavastu?" The sages replied, "Twelve leagues." "That is too close," thought the Bodhisattva.
column9: In Rājagṛha (rgyal po’i khab), from the palace, King Bimbisāra (gzugs can snying po) sees the Buddha begging for alms. The king then goes to a forest to visit the Buddha.

column5: Crossing the Ganges River, he travelled some distance and finally reached Rajagriha. He fashioned a begging bowl from oleander leaves and then entered the city to beg for alms.

King Bimbisara saw the Bodhisattva from the roof of his palace. He thought, "Renunciates such as him have stayed in this city, but there has never been another with such fine conduct." And then he praised him. The Bodhisattva came to rest beneith a white tree, or a Patala tree, at the base of a mountain.
column12: This section is much more extensive in the Vinaya passage with Bimbasara waxing eloquent on the qualities of the Bodhisattva in a series of Ślokas (seven-syllable lines)

column5: The king dispatched his scouts and learned where he was staying. The king and his retinue came before the Boddhisattva. They exchanged words of kindness and respect. Then the King said, "Begging alms is unbecoming for a young man in the prime of life. So I will offer you all you could desire. What is your caste? What is your family line?"

column4: བཀའ་སྩལ་པ། རྒྱལ་པོ་གངས་རི་ཉེ་བ་ན། ཡུལ་གྱི་ལྗོངས་ནི་འབྲུ་དག་དང་། །ནོར་རྣམས་ཀུན་གྱིས་གང་བ་ཡི། །ཀོ་ས་ལ་ཞེས་གྲགས་པ་ཡོད། །བུ་རམ་ཤིང་པ་ཉི་མའི་རུས། །ཤཱཀྱ་དག་ནི་དེ་ན་གནས། །རྒྱལ་པོ་ང་ནི་རྒྱལ་རིགས་ཏེ། །ང་ནི་འདོད་པ་དོན་མི་གཉེར། ཞེས་དང་། རྒྱལ་པོ་ང་ནི་བྱུང་མ་ཐག་ཏུ་ཡང་། །འདོད་པ་རྣམས་ལ་མི་དགའི་བློ་བསྐྱེད་ན། །འཇིགས་བྱེད་ཆོས་ཀྱི་དགྲ་བོར་གྱུར་པ་དག །བོར་བ་དེ་ཀོ་སླར་ཡང་ཇི་ལྟར་བླང་། ཞེས་སོགས་རྒྱ་ཆེར་གསུངས། གསོལ་པ།
column5: The Bodhisattva replied, "King, near the snowy mountain ranges Lies a country full of good grain And all manner of wealth. It is known as Kosala. There dwell the Shakyas, The Ishvaku clan, race of the sun. King, I am of the royal caste. I do not chase my desires." He continued, "King, since I first entered the world I have felt disinterest toward desires. My enemies, worldly things, so terrifying— I have just them cast off. Why would I take them up again?" Thus, he went on at length.

column5: "What will you gain with this ascetic practice?" asked the king. "Perfect enlightenment," he replied. The king requested, "When you attain this, please think of me.""I shall think of you," the Bodhisattva said.
Then the Bodhisattva travelled to the retreat center of several sages, located near Mount Vulture Heap.
The sages were enduring the trail of the five fives, standing on one leg, and other ascetic practices.
column7: Torture of the five fires. Diffusing smoke. Swimming. Dwelling place of various sages.
column9: The Buddha visits sages performing ascetic practices such as standing on a single leg, fire torment, walking on the water, and swallowing smoke and so forth in a forest. The Buddha also performs two of these practices.

column5: However much ascetic practice the sages performed, the Bodhisattva did twice as much. They named him Great Sage and Great Ascetic.

The Bodhisattva knew that their only goal was to reach a celestial realm. He thought, "They have entered a mistaken, ineffective path and will only fall back down." So he travelled to the retreat center of Arada Kalama.

At the dwelling of Arada Kalama and Udraka Ramaputra
column9: In a forest, the Buddha visits the sage, Ārāḍa-kālāma (ring ‘phur) dwelling in a hut.
column12: The canonical passage includes references to the following realms: that of Indra (brgya byin nyid), Brahmā (tshang pa nyid), and Māra (bdud nyid). [17b.2]

column5: From Arada Kalama the Bodhisattva requested oral instructions up to and including the sphere of nothingness. That night he achieved this sphere.

At dawn he asked Arada Kalama, "Have you realized this teaching on the sphere of nothingness?"
"I have," responded Arada Kalama.
"I also have realized this," said the Bodhisatva.
At this Arada Kalama said, "Well we very much alike! Join me, and together we wil lead this entire group."

The Bodhisattva thought, "Through this path alone I will not achieve knowledge, I will not achieve vision. I will not achieve complete enlightenment." So he travelled to Udraka Ramaputra's center. Here things were much as they were with Arada Kalama, with the exception that here he was able to achieve a contemplative absorption of the peak of existence called the sphere without discrimination or non-discrimination. After this he left Udraka Ramaputra's center and traveled to other places.
column9: He then visits the sage, Udraka-rāmaputra (lhag spyod) in a hut.
